summary: What would you say to the argument that Sansa is really Lady Bolton and should be referred to as such? Also same person claimed...
question: What would you say to the argument that Sansa is really Lady Bolton and should be referred to as such? Also same person claimed the Dreadfort should remain her property and the land shouldn't be parcelled out to loyal people as rewards as this would diminish the fortress due to lack of funds.
answer:
Well…she could make that argument, it’d just go into the legal weeds if she did, with some nasty implications for the standing of Jon’s regime. (I’m going to assume for a second that law and politics in the show are functional bits of worldbuilding, which they are not, and everything to do with Sansa and Ramsay proves it.) And she wouldn’t own the Dreadfort; she’d have widow’s rights to it. (Again, if this were anything like the books.)

First, are the Starks prepared to allow Roose’s right to the Dreadfort to stand for the period between his betrayal of the Starks and his murder? Jon argued to Dany that the feudal arrangement between Rickard and Aerys was void from Aerys’ betrayal; that would indicate to me that he would regard the feudal contract between the Starks and the Boltons void from the Red Wedding, and Roose was no longer Lord of the Dreadfort by the Starks’ consent. The title wasn’t Roose’s to give to his heir upon his death. Arguably.

Second, Ramsay. Even if Jon decided that the Dreadfort was Roose’s, passing to his heir as per usual, was Ramsay a legitimate heir? Ramsay was legitimised by Tommen. Any recognition of this is a recognition of Tommen’s legal authority (and this, the show has definitely ignored). As far as the Starks should be concerned, Ramsay was always a bastard. There may be Bolton cousins out there with claims to the Dreadfort the Starks would prefer to his.

Third, the marriage itself. Do the Starks want to recognise the validity of Sansa’s marriage to Ramsay? While there’s precedent for wedding vows said at swordpoint being binding (in the books), that also seems like a precedent that Jon might want to overrule for so many reasons. That would be a good positive development in the Northern legal system, inching the standard of consent required to make a binding marriage a bit higher.

Fourth, even if Jon decides Roose was able to pass his title and lands on, to Ramsay, and from him to his legal wife, whether he takes them away for Ramsay’s actions is definitely within his powers - Sansa’s argued rights to the lands and titles notwithstanding. That’s the sort of decision he gets to make. If he wants to parcel out that land to the people who actually supported him, he gets to do that. In practical political terms, his subjects would back him on this one.

Most importantly, however, is what Sansa wants. It’s clear to me that she rejects the marriage’s validity and prefers to build her political identity and power as a Stark. Who could blame her?

title: Winterfell’s Daughter. On Sansa Stark (part 12)
body:
I’ve previously written a series of posts that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10) and now season 3 (Part 11). In my previous post I wrote that:

If Sansa’s season 2 arc was about enduring abuse, then her season 3 arc is dealing with hope of an escape - a hope held out by different political players of varying trustworthiness.

However, her season 3 arc is also very much about her political status as Robb Stark’s heir apparent. In short, she has become the Key to the North and as such she’s become an important piece on the political chessboard and to all the major political players in King’s Landing and that is why Petyr Baelish, Lord Varys, Tywin Lannister and the Tyrells begin to take an interest in her. In this post I’m going to take a closer look at her very first interactions with the members of House Tyrell, which is establishing itself as a major power player in the Game of Thrones. Sansa has several interactions with the Tyrells but in this post I’ll limit my analysis to one scene in particular since it is interesting how the Tyrells at first are only interested in Sansa because they’ve heard some disturbing rumours about King Joffrey, Margaery Tyrell’s intended. It is also a scene that I found much more disturbing during my re-watch than when I first watched in years ago.

SECRETS, LIES AND TRUTH - LUNCH WITH THE TYRELLS

In my metas about Margery Tyrell’s season 3 arc (x), I noted that she immediately made her presence felt in King’s Landing through a clever deployment of soft power, which has secured her the goodwill of the common people. At the same time her grandmother Olenna, called the Queen of Thorns, conducts the more direct political negotiations with both Tywin and Tyrion Lannister. However, that is not all - in the very first episode it becomes clear that they are also taking an interest in Sansa, due to the disturbing rumours that they’ve heard about Joffrey’s abuse of her. Thus, they are quick to invite her to a private lunch in the lush gardens of the Red Keep.

It is both sweet and a bit sad to see how happy and excited Sansa is that there are some people that want to spend time with her, who are initially kind to her and who even made the effort to find out what her favorite food is.

Her hopeful little smile here shows how incredibly grateful she is that someone is seeking out her company and it really drives home just how isolated and lonely Sansa has been at the royal court - shunned by the people who have been standing idly by as she’s been abused in public. 

She’s being charmed by the Tyrells and you can see how she’s beginning to think that things might change for her. Sadly, as Sansa, Olenna and Margaery sit down for a talk, it quickly becomes clear that the reason they have invited her to lunch is because they want something from her. It is worth watching the entire scene, especially the private conversation between the three women (timestamp; 2:22) because this conversation turns out to be rather traumatic for Sansa.

Sansa’s happiness is shattered the moment that Olenna Tyrell asks her to tell the truth about Joffrey. This turn in the conversation makes Sansa feel incredibly nervous and unsafe – she stammers and her eyes dart wildly about, as if she’s looking for an escape.

Sansa: I… I…

Olenna: You, you. Who else know better? We’ve heard some troubling tales. Is there any truth to them?

Cut to a close-up of Margaery, tilting her head, looking at Sansa. Then the camera cuts to a close-up of Sansa who looks down, having lost her happy smile. She’s clearly scared but perhaps also disappointed that these people have only sought out her company because they want something from her.

Olenna (VO): Has this boy mistreated you? … Has he ripped out your tongue?

Olenna really comes across as a bully here, especially when you consider that Sansa is an abuse victim. 

Sansa (stammers): King Joffrey, His Grace is very fair and handsome and as brave as a lion.

It is clear that Sansa is very uncomfortable and that she’s lying. Sansa’s response tells us that she doesn’t trust the Tyrells, and I also expect that she doesn’t react well to Olenna pressuring her like that (it is too similar to the way her abusers demanding answers from her), which we’ve seen in previous episodes. In fact, Olenna’s method is reminiscent of how Cersei Lannister interacts with Sansa (x), except that Olenna is more directly aggressive than Cersei.

Olenna: Yes, all Lannisters are lions… But how kind is he? How clever? Has he a good heart? A gentle hand?

Margaery: I’m to be his wife. I only want to know what that means.

I believe that Margaery is honest here. Then we get an OTS shot of Margaery, from Sansa’s POV. The camera work reinforces the POV structure – we experience this conversation mainly through Sansa point of view. The camera cuts to a close-up of Sansa, her mouth is slightly open. This is a reaction shot to Margaery’s utterance. Sansa is hesitating, pondering whether she should tell Margaery the truth. Margaery’s soft approach seems to work better than Olenna’s heavy-handed bullying. This moment, where Sansa is on the brink of telling the truth about Joffrey, is ruined when a servant appears. Sansa turns to look at him – and when she turns back, her expression is closed-off! She’s afraid of being overheard – she knows that there are spies everywhere in the Red Keep. Sansa lowers her head quickly and her gaze follows the retreating servant.

Olenna (leaning forward towards Sansa): Are you frightened child? No need for that.

She offers Sansa a lemon cake – her favorite food – in an attempt to calm her down.

Olenna: We’re only women here. Tell us the truth. No harm will come to you.

OTS shot of Sansa with her gaze lowered (from Margaery’s POV).

Sansa: My father always told the truth.

She lifts her gaze but it is clear that she isn’t looking at either woman. An avoidance of a gaze is often a defense mechanism. Sansa is scared and she doesn’t trust these women - and Olenna is making things worse by pressuring her since it is the way that Sansa’s abusers also act.

Olenna: Yes, he had that reputation. And they named him traitor and took his head.

A close-up of Sansa’s face, her gaze unfocused. She looks lost in thought and she looks so defeated. Oleanna is handling her all wrong, now invoking the traumatic experience of her father’s death. 

Sansa: Joffrey…

Close-up of Sansa. She looks at Olenna now, her expression is both angry and anguished. Her eyes move, shifting her gaze to Margaery.

(GIF set by @aryaestarks)

Her lip quivers, she’s close to tears. Cut to Olenna looking thoughtful. Cut to OTS shot of Margaery (from Sansa’s POV).

Margaery (gently): Go on.

Cut to OTS shoot of Sansa, Margaery’s POV. Sansa lifts her gaze to Margaery. Then she starts to stammer because she’s afraid now that’s she just told the brutal truth to a pair of stranger that she doesn’t know she can trust.

Sansa: I can’t. I never meant…

Cut to OTS shot of Margaery, looking sad.

Sansa (VO): My father was a traitor.

Cut to OTS shot of Sansa (from Olenna’s POV).

Sansa: My brother as well. I have traitor’s blood.

Sansa’s eyes dart nervously between the two women. She is obviously scared and she’s reverted to tonelessly repeating the things that her abusers tell her. This is where I really began to dislike Olenna because she speaks to Sansa very much like her abusers do – relentlessly prodding her for answers when she is so obviously scared. Olenna gets her results after much prodding and by making Sansa angry – but she also rips open a painful wound and her aggressive stance makes Sansa retreat into the behaviour that she uses to protect herself – a rote litany where she repeats the things that her abusers tell her. Olenna is burning bridges here and you get the hint that Margaery’s more gentle approach might have been a better idea.

Sansa: Please, don’t make me say anymore.

At this point Sansa is pleading with them – she is terrified because she knows that she’ll get a beating (at minimum) if she is overheard. This is so incredibly sad.

Margaery: She’s terrified, Grandmother. Look at her.

Close-up of Olenna, leaning forward.

Olenna: Speak freely, child.

Cut to a shot of all three women, Sansa in center frame with her front to the camera, flanked by the two Tyrell women, their backs to the camera.

Olenna: We would never betray your confidence, I swear it.

Slow zoom on Sansa with a cut to a close-up of her face, her lips quivering and she raises a tearful gaze as ominous music begins to play. 

After being bullied and re-traumatized, Sansa finally tells the basic truth about what Joffrey is: a monster. Yet both Olenna and Margaery react to this in  a manner that seems rather cavalier and unbothered.

Cut to a close-up of Olenna.

Olenna: Ah.

Olenna turns to look at Margaery who simply shrugs as she eats a grape. 

Close-up shot of Sansa, her eyes wet with unshed tears.

Sansa: Please, don’t stop the wedding.

Cut to OTS shot of Olenna (Sansa’s POV).

Olenna: Have to fear. The Lord Oaf of Highgarden is determined that Margaery shall be queen.

Cut to close-up of Sansa, she’s close to tears now. Then there’s a cut to an OTS shot of Margaery (Sansa’s POV): Margaery looks thoughtful, perhaps disappointed and she gives a little smile to Sansa.

Cut to a close-up of Olenna.

Olenna: Even so, we thank you for the truth…

The scene ends with a medium shot of Sansa, looking sad and dejected. She sits completely still, frozen like a statue as the camera keeps the focus on her. 

What had initially been such a source of happiness to an abused and lonely girl turned out to be a horrible experience where Sansa once again learns that the powerful people of the royal court only care about what they can get from her, not for her as a person - and this is absolutely heartbreaking. Once again Sansa had her hopes lifted only to have them smashed. 

This scene is, in many ways, very close to how it plays out in the book (though with less characters present). Most of the dialogue is taken directly from the book (ASoS) and like in the show, Sansa is absolutely terrified throughout the whole interview whilst Olenna keeps pressuring her. In the books, we know Sansa’s thoughts because we are in her head – we see what she thinks and we feel what she feels. That kind of interiority cannot really be recreated on television where the audience is placed on the outside when it comes to the inner life of the characters. Sansa’s acute fear during this interview is conveyed entirely through Sophie Turner’s acting: her facial expressions, her gestures and the modulation of her voice. It is fortunate that Turner is as talented as she is when it comes to non-verbal cues.

This entire scene makes me so sad for Sansa. She was so excited and delighted that someone was seeking out her company, looking as though they would be kind to her – only for her to realize that they want something from her. Even worse, Olenna basically bullies Sansa into telling the truth about Joffrey and then they both she and Margaery act rather cavalierly, as if the truth doesn’t matter (or that is what it would look like to Sansa). When they have finally gotten what they wanted, they continue as if nothing unusual has happened whilst Sansa just silently sits there, in emotional turmoil and bitterly disappointed. 


To be continued…

(GIFs not mine)

She is obviously scared and she’s reverted to tonelessly repeating the things that her abusers tell her. This is where I really began to dislike Olenna because she speaks to Sansa very much like her abusers do – relentlessly prodding her for answers when she is so obviously scared. Olenna gets her results after much prodding and by making Sansa angry – but she also rips open a painful wound and her aggressive stance makes Sansa retreat into the behaviour that she uses to protect herself – a rote litany where she repeats the things that her abusers tell her. Olenna is burning bridges here and you get the hint that Margaery’s more gentle approach might have been a better idea.

Sansa: Please, don’t make me say anymore.

At this point Sansa is pleading with them – she is terrified because she knows that she’ll get a beating (at minimum) if she is overheard. This is so incredibly sad.

Margaery: She’s terrified, Grandmother. Look at her.

Close-up of Olenna, leaning forward.

Olenna: Speak freely, child.

Cut to a shot of all three women, Sansa in center frame with her front to the camera, flanked by the two Tyrell women, their backs to the camera.

Olenna: We would never betray your confidence, I swear it.

Slow zoom on Sansa with a cut to a close-up of her face, her lips quivering and she raises a tearful gaze as ominous music begins to play. 

After being bullied and re-traumatized, Sansa finally tells the basic truth about what Joffrey is: a monster. Yet both Olenna and Margaery react to this in  a manner that seems rather cavalier and unbothered.

Cut to a close-up of Olenna.

Olenna: Ah.

Olenna turns to look at Margaery who simply shrugs as she eats a grape. 

Close-up shot of Sansa, her eyes wet with unshed tears.

Sansa: Please, don’t stop the wedding.

Cut to OTS shot of Olenna (Sansa’s POV).

Olenna: Have to fear. The Lord Oaf of Highgarden is determined that Margaery shall be queen.

Cut to close-up of Sansa, she’s close to tears now. Then there’s a cut to an OTS shot of Margaery (Sansa’s POV): Margaery looks thoughtful, perhaps disappointed and she gives a little smile to Sansa.

Cut to a close-up of Olenna.

Olenna: Even so, we thank you for the truth…

The scene ends with a medium shot of Sansa, looking sad and dejected. She sits completely still, frozen like a statue as the camera keeps the focus on her. 

What had initially been such a source of happiness to an abused and lonely girl turned out to be a horrible experience where Sansa once again learns that the powerful people of the royal court only care about what they can get from her, not for her as a person - and this is absolutely heartbreaking. Once again Sansa had her hopes lifted only to have them smashed. 

This scene is, in many ways, very close to how it plays out in the book (though with less characters present). Most of the dialogue is taken directly from the book (ASoS) and like in the show, Sansa is absolutely terrified throughout the whole interview whilst Olenna keeps pressuring her. In the books, we know Sansa’s thoughts because we are in her head – we see what she thinks and we feel what she feels. That kind of interiority cannot really be recreated on television where the audience is placed on the outside when it comes to the inner life of the characters. Sansa’s acute fear during this interview is conveyed entirely through Sophie Turner’s acting: her facial expressions, her gestures and the modulation of her voice. It is fortunate that Turner is as talented as she is when it comes to non-verbal cues.

This entire scene makes me so sad for Sansa. She was so excited and delighted that someone was seeking out her company, looking as though they would be kind to her – only for her to realize that they want something from her. Even worse, Olenna basically bullies Sansa into telling the truth about Joffrey and then they both she and Margaery act rather cavalierly, as if the truth doesn’t matter (or that is what it would look like to Sansa). When they have finally gotten what they wanted, they continue as if nothing unusual has happened whilst Sansa just silently sits there, in emotional turmoil and bitterly disappointed. 


To be continued…

(GIFs not mine)

I’ve previously written a series of posts that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10) and now season 3 (Part 11). In my previous post I wrote that:

If Sansa’s season 2 arc was about enduring abuse, then her season 3 arc is dealing with hope of an escape - a hope held out by different political players of varying trustworthiness.

However, her season 3 arc is also very much about her political status as Robb Stark’s heir apparent. In short, she has become the Key to the North and as such she’s become an important piece on the political chessboard and to all the major political players in King’s Landing and that is why Petyr Baelish, Lord Varys, Tywin Lannister and the Tyrells begin to take an interest in her. In this post I’m going to take a closer look at her very first interactions with the members of House Tyrell, which is establishing itself as a major power player in the Game of Thrones. Sansa has several interactions with the Tyrells but in this post I’ll limit my analysis to one scene in particular since it is interesting how the Tyrells at first are only interested in Sansa because they’ve heard some disturbing rumours about King Joffrey, Margaery Tyrell’s intended. It is also a scene that I found much more disturbing during my re-watch than when I first watched in years ago.

[[MORE]]

SECRETS, LIES AND TRUTH - LUNCH WITH THE TYRELLS

In my metas about Margery Tyrell’s season 3 arc (x), I noted that she immediately made her presence felt in King’s Landing through a clever deployment of soft power, which has secured her the goodwill of the common people. At the same time her grandmother Olenna, called the Queen of Thorns, conducts the more direct political negotiations with both Tywin and Tyrion Lannister. However, that is not all - in the very first episode it becomes clear that they are also taking an interest in Sansa, due to the disturbing rumours that they’ve heard about Joffrey’s abuse of her. Thus, they are quick to invite her to a private lunch in the lush gardens of the Red Keep.

It is both sweet and a bit sad to see how happy and excited Sansa is that there are some people that want to spend time with her, who are initially kind to her and who even made the effort to find out what her favorite food is.

Her hopeful little smile here shows how incredibly grateful she is that someone is seeking out her company and it really drives home just how isolated and lonely Sansa has been at the royal court - shunned by the people who have been standing idly by as she’s been abused in public. 

She’s being charmed by the Tyrells and you can see how she’s beginning to think that things might change for her. Sadly, as Sansa, Olenna and Margaery sit down for a talk, it quickly becomes clear that the reason they have invited her to lunch is because they want something from her. It is worth watching the entire scene, especially the private conversation between the three women (timestamp; 2:22) because this conversation turns out to be rather traumatic for Sansa.

Sansa’s happiness is shattered the moment that Olenna Tyrell asks her to tell the truth about Joffrey. This turn in the conversation makes Sansa feel incredibly nervous and unsafe – she stammers and her eyes dart wildly about, as if she’s looking for an escape.

Sansa: I… I…

Olenna: You, you. Who else know better? We’ve heard some troubling tales. Is there any truth to them?

Cut to a close-up of Margaery, tilting her head, looking at Sansa. Then the camera cuts to a close-up of Sansa who looks down, having lost her happy smile. She’s clearly scared but perhaps also disappointed that these people have only sought out her company because they want something from her.

Olenna (VO): Has this boy mistreated you? … Has he ripped out your tongue?

Olenna really comes across as a bully here, especially when you consider that Sansa is an abuse victim. 

Sansa (stammers): King Joffrey, His Grace is very fair and handsome and as brave as a lion.

It is clear that Sansa is very uncomfortable and that she’s lying. Sansa’s response tells us that she doesn’t trust the Tyrells, and I also expect that she doesn’t react well to Olenna pressuring her like that (it is too similar to the way her abusers demanding answers from her), which we’ve seen in previous episodes. In fact, Olenna’s method is reminiscent of how Cersei Lannister interacts with Sansa (x), except that Olenna is more directly aggressive than Cersei.

Olenna: Yes, all Lannisters are lions… But how kind is he? How clever? Has he a good heart? A gentle hand?

Margaery: I’m to be his wife. I only want to know what that means.

I believe that Margaery is honest here. Then we get an OTS shot of Margaery, from Sansa’s POV. The camera work reinforces the POV structure – we experience this conversation mainly through Sansa point of view. The camera cuts to a close-up of Sansa, her mouth is slightly open. This is a reaction shot to Margaery’s utterance. Sansa is hesitating, pondering whether she should tell Margaery the truth. Margaery’s soft approach seems to work better than Olenna’s heavy-handed bullying. This moment, where Sansa is on the brink of telling the truth about Joffrey, is ruined when a servant appears. Sansa turns to look at him – and when she turns back, her expression is closed-off! She’s afraid of being overheard – she knows that there are spies everywhere in the Red Keep. Sansa lowers her head quickly and her gaze follows the retreating servant.

Olenna (leaning forward towards Sansa): Are you frightened child? No need for that.

She offers Sansa a lemon cake – her favorite food – in an attempt to calm her down.

Olenna: We’re only women here. Tell us the truth. No harm will come to you.

OTS shot of Sansa with her gaze lowered (from Margaery’s POV).

Sansa: My father always told the truth.

She lifts her gaze but it is clear that she isn’t looking at either woman. An avoidance of a gaze is often a defense mechanism. Sansa is scared and she doesn’t trust these women - and Olenna is making things worse by pressuring her since it is the way that Sansa’s abusers also act.

Olenna: Yes, he had that reputation. And they named him traitor and took his head.

A close-up of Sansa’s face, her gaze unfocused. She looks lost in thought and she looks so defeated. Oleanna is handling her all wrong, now invoking the traumatic experience of her father’s death. 

Sansa: Joffrey…

Close-up of Sansa. She looks at Olenna now, her expression is both angry and anguished. Her eyes move, shifting her gaze to Margaery.

(GIF set by @aryaestarks)

Her lip quivers, she’s close to tears. Cut to Olenna looking thoughtful. Cut to OTS shot of Margaery (from Sansa’s POV).

Margaery (gently): Go on.

Cut to OTS shoot of Sansa, Margaery’s POV. Sansa lifts her gaze to Margaery. Then she starts to stammer because she’s afraid now that’s she just told the brutal truth to a pair of stranger that she doesn’t know she can trust.

Sansa: I can’t. I never meant…

Cut to OTS shot of Margaery, looking sad.

Sansa (VO): My father was a traitor.

Cut to OTS shot of Sansa (from Olenna’s POV).

Sansa: My brother as well. I have traitor’s blood.

Jon: that's amazing.

I'm interested in fantasy, fantasy art, A Song of Ice and Fire / Game of Thrones, SanSan, vegan recipes and creative writing.
My main blog with my own fanfiction, drawings and some poems:
http://maracuyakongeen.livejournal.com/

title: SanSan writing prompt
body:
Canon-era AU

Sandor’s trousers get torn (perhaps Stranger’s doing?).

Thus, Sansa accidentally gets a perfect view of Sandor’s delicious behind.

Of course, prim Sansa would never admit it, but on the inside…

Bonus if Sandor notices Sansa notice.

Extra bonus if some washerwomen are gossiping about Sandor’s assets later, and Sansa plays dumb while secretely inching closer so as not to miss a single glorious detail.

Anyone? Pretty please?

*shameless begging

summary: What’s your opinion on Sansa and LF’s plot to poison SR? On one hand I don’t think she knows for a fact that’s what he’s doing...
question: What’s your opinion on Sansa and LF’s plot to poison SR? On one hand I don’t think she knows for a fact that’s what he’s doing but on the other hand he’s not being subtle. Sansa’s not stupid and it’s clear he’s up to some shady shit and expects Sweetrobin to die. A part of me feels like Sansa does know (subconsciously) but refuses to acknowledge it because she’s a child dependent on LF & she’s looking after her own well being before SR’s which isn’t admirable but is understandable.
answer:
The idea that Sansa knows that Littlefinger is killing Sweetrobin is a lie pushed by Littlefinger stans who want her to be Persephone to Littlefinger’s Hades or some other bullshit. Sansa knows Littlefinger is dangerous, she knows SR is right to be afraid of Littlefinger, what she doesn’t know is Littlefinger’s full plan. Her marriage of Harry the Heir is meant to tie her to the Vale so that she can be given an army to take back the kingdom she has an actual claim to. The reason she’s not marrying SR but SR’s heir is because he is too young. The reason Sansa accepts the inevitability of SR’s death is because SR is a sickly child. If being afraid of Littlefinger forces her to ignore all of that so that she can pretend she doesn’t know about the poisoning of SR, then that’s a new trait in Sansa because she has been in constant danger since the end of book 1 and that didn’t stop her for helping and protecting people. She was assaulted by rioters and she still wanted to give them bread. She spoke up for Dontos, she warned Margaery about Joffrey. Sansa is much braver than people give her credit for and much more lucid. If you believe that side of the fandom then you’d think Sansa spends half her time being an unreliable narrator. I mean we have a few instance of Sansa suppressing her memory due to trauma that doesn’t mean she’s ignoring everything important.

Most importantly, Sansa is merely annoyed with SR because he is an understandably annoying child but she takes care of him. People think her putting up boundaries between the two of them is hate and a sign that she would OK with his death are wrong. She wants him to grow up and marry. She carries him down the mountain despite the danger. Sansa doesn’t want this child hurt and she’s brave enough to stand up to Littlefinger if he tries to kill him in front of her. People can’t use the Lysa incident because Sansa didn’t see Littlefinger pushing Lysa to death coming.

There are so many arguments about this.

summary: It would surprise me that people ignore what a poor parent Ned was to Sansa but then he's male and so many misogynistic people...
question: It would surprise me that people ignore what a poor parent Ned was to Sansa but then he's male and so many misogynistic people hate Sansa, coupled with the way the show treats him as a saint while ignoring Cat and there being other worse parents so he's able to get off the hook for the way he treats Sansa.
answer:
Pretty much. I would never say dads irl never go unappreciated and they definitely deserve as much respect as moms, but society does often praise them for doing the bare minimum at times, and that’s ridiculously easy to do in a place like Westeros where nobody but the abused kid bats an eye at being chained to a wall to make you “man up”.

Ned was busy on his investigation, yes, but… so? All the more reason to ensure his daughters had more protection since he wouldn’t be able to. People say he was used to Sansa being obedient and had no idea she would go to Cersei. Well, if he took five minutes to spend any time with her, he might notice that not only is Sansa growing up, but she’s started her rebellious teen phase right before his eyes (thanks in no small part to his double standards with Arya).

Oh, and I love that Cat is a horrible parent for “nagging” Robb (translation: telling him what’s what even if he’s too much of a teenager to appreciate that she’s right) when she should be back in the kitchen wiping Rickon’s little nose and leaving the war stuff for the menfolk to handle, as if the Starks don’t have a castle full of perfectly competent servants who love the boys and as if Robb isn’t badly in need of competent advisors he can trust. Or during her brief stay at Bran’s bedside, too afraid and grieving to even eat, much less run her castle, because grief is only allowed if it’s the beautiful, gray-tinted grief Ned has of his sister. (Women can cry but not be depressed, it’s just not sexy.) But Ned letting Arya wander off alone in strange woods playing with poisonous plants or be so negligent with Sansa that she’s made to get drunk with Joffrey once and is escorted by a grown man Ned happens to dislike without anyone knowing (which he never found out about because he never bothers to ask Sansa anything)? Someone bake a “Congrats on not starving your kids” cookie cake.

Ned is very loving and devoted in a general sense, but my gosh, sometimes it’s hard to not shake my head at him. Fans really are bad about using the “well, at least he’s trying!” excuse or blame Sansa for her and Ned’s relationship being so poor, as if it’s the child’s job to parent the parent. Catelyn would never, ever get away with treating any of their kids the way he treats- or doesn’t treat- Sansa.

Which is what really gets me. If the roles were reversed, people would coo and wipe a pearly tear away at seeing Ned refusing to leave Bran’s side. I’m sure if he said anything like that to Jon, any hate he got for it would be far less overwhelming than what Cat gets. They would cheer “Yeah, Ned, you put that mouthy kid in his place!” when he gives Robb brutally honest advice he doesn’t like hearing. And as we already know, his favoritism of Arya is seen as nothing less than utterly heart-warming and not at all exclusive or unfair to the other Starklings as Cat’s closeness with Sansa is.

Plus he’s dead and had a good fanbase to begin with, so like his own romanticizing of his sister’s memory, fans only want to remember the good of him and don’t want to think he did anything wrong, ever.

blog.description: Official member of the Sansa Stark Defense Squad. Certified Jonsa Trash. Also a Nick Hoult loyalist since 2011.

tags: literally the biggest double standard in the show
summary: "Feminist" GOT audience: Dænerys and Arya are so cool, so feminist. They are strong. They are badasses. Both don't fit the...
body:
“Feminist” GOT audience: Dænerys and Arya are so cool, so feminist. They are strong. They are badasses. Both don’t fit the stereotype of princesses who need to be saved. They are role models. They don’t owe nothing to men. They fight for what they believe. They are amazing! Writers, please take note.

Also “feminist” GOT audience: I mean, Sansa is so useless, she is so annoying. She doesn’t know how to fight and she is so bitchy! She treated so bad Arya! And why she didn’t love back Tyrion? He was so kind to her! She should be grateful to be married to him instead of that little shit Joffrey who she was so in love with him! She could have tried at least!! She is so bossy and power hungry! She is just too girly and cries the whole time!! She wanted Jon dead in the BotB! It was Littlefinger who saved all! She wanted to be crowned Queen for doing absolutely nothing!!!!! SHE WILL BETRAY JON, SHE IS JUST WAITING FOR THE RIGHT MOMENT!!! JUST LIKE SHE BETRAYED LITTLEFINGER WHY WOULD YOU KILL YOUR GREATEST ALLIE OF ALL??!! IF SHE BRETRAYED HER FATHER SHE WILL BETRAY JON AND HER WHOLE FAMILY!!! SHE NEEDS TO DIE BY THE END!!!!!!

Also “feminist” GOT audience: I mean, Sansa is so useless, she is so annoying. She doesn’t know how to fight and she is so bitchy! She treated so bad Arya! And why she didn’t love back Tyrion? He was so kind to her! She should be grateful to be married to him instead of that little shit Joffrey who she was so in love with him! She could have tried at least!! She is so bossy and power hungry! She is just too girly and cries the whole time!! She wanted Jon dead in the BotB! It was Littlefinger who saved all! She wanted to be crowned Queen for doing absolutely nothing!!!!! SHE WILL BETRAY JON, SHE IS JUST WAITING FOR THE RIGHT MOMENT!!! JUST LIKE SHE BETRAYED LITTLEFINGER WHY WOULD YOU KILL YOUR GREATEST ALLIE OF ALL??!! IF SHE BRETRAYED HER FATHER SHE WILL BETRAY JON AND HER WHOLE FAMILY!!! SHE NEEDS TO DIE BY THE END!!!!!!

blog.title: Queen Of Songs
blog.description: 🎶Trust Each Other & Winter Has Come (Plus Ships/TV shows/Movies/Books I love)Winterfellsummerose17 on AO3 :)

summary:
You know that hashtag that went around a few months ago? When I first saw myself in whatever form of entertainment? 
Sansa Stark...
body:
You know that hashtag that went around a few months ago? When I first saw myself in whatever form of entertainment?

Sansa Stark immediately came to mind. Before she became my favorite female character, Katniss Everdeen was. But even when Katniss was my favorite I never fully connected to her as I did with Sansa.

I see so much of myself in her. Sansa has had to overcome so much pain in her life, yet chooses to continue to be brave and kind. All she wants is respect and genuine love from others. She’s observant and uses her courtesy as a weapon. She admits her wrongs and learns from them. Thank you GRRM for this awesome character. She also has two of my favorite quotes from a book.🐺🐺🐺 “My skin has turned to porcelain, to ivory, to steel.” & “Drifting snowflakes brushed her face as light as lover’s kisses, and melted on her cheeks. She could feel the snow on her lashes, taste it on her lips. It was the taste of Winterfell. The taste of innocence. The taste of dreams.”

this probably won't be the final version of this
summary: Oh look, more again, and a real beginning!
title: Oh look, more again, and a real beginning!
body:
Consider this Part 1.  Here’s Part 2, and Part 3. More of Margaery’s POV.

Margaery pulled the curtain back from the window of the carriage and peered out at the empty tundra. The further North they rode, it seemed, the more barren and bleaker the landscape became.  It was especially strange to Margaery, who grew up in the lush green hills of the Reach, where it seemed not a second passed without the cheerful chirp of birds or the caress of a pleasant summer breeze.  Whatever breeze blew in the North was nippy at best, and she thought that fact would be harder to adjust to than the equally biting Northern people.

Her grandmother, ornery and vociferous as she was always expected to be around family, had already made her thoughts about the North and its people quite clear.  As far as Olenna Tyrell was concerned, the entire kingdom could break off at the Neck and float away with no significant losses and take its walls and wildlings and weirwood trees with it.  Margaery of course knew that most of her vitriol was just irritated noise-making, because Olenna certainly didn’t want the North to float away when she could still take advantage of it.

That was why they were here in this carriage after all, riding down the long dirt road to Winterfell. Olenna and Margaery’s father, Mace, saw an opportunity to dig Tyrell fingers into the pie of Northern politics, and they weren’t about to miss their chance.  One year ago, they sent a raven to Eddard Stark offering Margaery as a marriage prospect to his eldest son Robb.  Lord Stark refused on the grounds that Robb was already betrothed to a woman from the Westerlands, but then offered an unorthodox yet appealing counter proposal.  

Lord Stark was a lucky man, blessed by the gods with six healthy children.  Margaery diligently ran through the names she had been given for probably the hundredth time: Robb, Jon (the bastard boy), Bran, Rickon, Arya, and Sansa.  It was the last name that sent a zing of anticipation through Margaery.  Who would ever have imagined that instead of the eldest son of the North, she’d be marrying the eldest daughter?  It was certainly unexpected of Ned Stark, uptight traditionalist that he was always described to be, to name his oldest daughter as a worthy candidate for sealing a Stark-Tyrell alliance.  Unexpected, but exciting, rather than worrying.

Sansa Stark… She’d heard stories of course.  She’d sought them out after the betrothal was announced.  As far South as she had been in High Garden, there hadn’t been much to hear, but she knew that Sansa was supposed to beautiful, the spitting image of her mother with hair the color of fire and eyes like chipped ice. Supposedly she and her siblings had never left Winterfell, not even once, which was… odd.  Margaery knew that the Starks were friendly with their bannermen as well as several other noble houses, the Arryns, Tullys, and Baratheons in particular.  Noble daughters weren’t sent to other families as wards the way sons were, but sometimes they were sent to be handmaidens to other ladies.  But it seemed such ventures were never considered for the Stark children. Peculiar indeed.

She wondered what Sansa Stark might possibly know of the South, shut away as she was in the North. Well… she supposed she would soon find out, as the carriage was cresting the final hill overlooking the great keep of Winterfell.  It was certainly impressive, if a bit plain.  Margaery was used to the elaborate palaces of the Reach, where ornamentation was the most important part of any given structure.  Winterfell, and indeed the rest of the Northern castles, seemed to eschew adornment.  As they neared the large front gates, it became clear that no stone had been wasted on anything without explicit practical purpose.  The walls were gray and imposing, the gatehouses tall and forbidding.  The towers and great hall that she could glimpse behind the walls were built for winter, built to endure rather than to impress, though they did impress.  Truly, this was a keep befitting of the Kings of Winter, as the Starks were once known.

The carriage stopped when their procession reached the gates.  Margaery could hear the rattling and creaking as they opened. Her grandmother peeked out the window at this time, snorting softly and derisively.  The carriage started moving again as they rode into the grand courtyard of the seat of the North.
